title: 111_s591
content: The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for the purposes of addressing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission's composition, duties, powers, staff, compensation, security clearances, reports, and termination are outlined in the Act. The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission to evaluate potential improvements in the management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission is tasked with submitting a report to Congress with findings and recommendations to improve the approach for managing defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, high-level waste, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. Each member must meet specific qualifications. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. Members must be prominent US citizens with expertise in engineering, science, energy, government, law, or foreign affairs. All members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and the Chairperson is appointed under subsection (a)(5). The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed by leaders, will be chaired by the Chairperson. The Commission will hold meetings as needed, with a quorum of five members. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation, providing funding for storage and management, exploring cost-sharing options with private industry, and establishing centralized interim storage facilities. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for spent nuclear fuel management, including interim storage facilities in communities, research on advanced fuel cycle technologies, and transferring spent fuel inventories to the Department of Energy. Additionally, they are requiring the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks for public safety and security. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for spent nuclear fuel management, including deep geologic disposal and interim strategies for treatment of defense wastes. They will consult with various stakeholders and submit recommendations on fee disposition. The Commission will recommend how to manage spent nuclear fuel and analyze the financial impacts on the government's liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act. They will submit a final report to Congress with their findings and recommendations. The Commission will recommend how to manage spent nuclear fuel and analyze the financial impacts on the government's liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act. They will submit a final report to Congress with their findings and recommendations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather evidence, and administer oaths. They can also enter into contracts and obtain information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out their duties under this Act. The Commission has the authority to gather information from federal agencies for their duties. They can request administrative support and services from the General Services Administration and other government departments as needed. The Commission may request support services and use postal services as authorized by law. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and staff support is authorized. The Chairperson of the Commission may appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain federal employment rules. Staff members are considered federal employees for specific purposes under the law. The Commission may appoint staff and set their compensation without following federal employment rules. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can also procure expert services at specified rates. SEC. 9. Compensation for Commission members not to exceed the daily equivalent of level IV pay under title 5, United States Code. Travel expenses allowed for Commission members in the same manner as Government service employees under title 5, United States Code. SEC. 10. Security clearances. SEC. 10. SECURITY CLEARANCES. The Federal agencies will cooperate with the Commission to provide appropriate security clearances to members and staff. Access to classified information requires the necessary security clearances. SEC. 11. REPORTS. SEC. 11. REPORTS. The Commission will release an interim report within 1 year and a final report within 2 years. The final report will include agreed findings, individual opinions, and public comments. SEC. 12. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds necessary for implementing the Act are authorized. SEC. 13. TERMINATION. The authority of the Commission terminates 180 days after the final report is submitted. During this period, the Commission can conclude its activities, provide testimony to Congress, and disseminate the final report.
